div.head: A Moderate ANSWER UNTO Dr. BASTWICKS Book; CALLED, Jndependencie not Gods Ordinance.
div.p: PA≈ø≈øing by many things le≈ø≈øe con≈øiderable, becau≈øe I intend brevity; In the 7th. page of the Doctors booke, There is a twofold Que≈øtion betweene them called PRESBYTERIANS and their Brethren who are termed INDEPENDENTS; The fir≈øt is, concerning the Government of the Church, viz. Whether it be Presbyterian-Dependen, or Presbyterian-Independent? The ≈øecond Que≈øtion is, concerning the Gathering of CHURCHES.

Touching the former Que≈øtion concerning the Government of the Church, the Doctor acknowledgeth in the ≈øame 7th. page, that the Brethren on both ≈øides agree, that the Government of the church is a Pre≈øbyterian-Government, both acknowledging a Pre≈øbyterie. But whether it be Dependent, or Independent is the maine thing in the que≈øtion, which the Doctor doth determine, and ≈øaith in the Title page of his book he hath evidently Proved. 'That the Pre≈øbyterian-Government-Dependent is Gods Ordinance, and not the byterian-Government-Independent.

I intend not to ≈øtrive with the Doctor about wordes, and therefore touching the two Termes, to wit, Dependent, and Independent; I ≈øhall onely ≈øay this at pre≈øent: That if by Independent the the Doctor indeede mean (as it doth appear ≈øo to my under≈øtanding by many pa≈ø≈øages in his booke, he doth intend) a Pre≈øbyterian-Government, which hath not Dependencie upon any in matters meerly Eccle≈øia≈øticall (but upon the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt, Who is the Head of the Church) And if by Dependent hee al≈øo indendeth (as in many other pa≈ø≈øages in his booke ≈øeemeth to me to be his meaning)Pag. 8.10. Pag. 14.15.17.18. a Presbyterian-Government, which hath a Dependencie upon a ≈øupream Judicature of a Common-councell of Presbyters, and who mu≈øt in matters Eccle≈øia≈øticall be ≈øubiect unto the Decrees, Sentences, Con≈øtitutions, and Commandments of a Common-councell, Colledge or Con≈øi≈øtorie of Cla≈ø≈øicall, Provinciall, or Synodicall Presbyters; Then I do conceive the Doctor hath not proved, (nor will he ever be able to prove) That the Presbyterian-Government-Dependent is Gods Ordinance; And I hope to make the contrary plainly appear both from cleere Texts of Scripture, and the Doctors owne bookes. And ≈øeeing that the Doctor hath in the 6th. p. of his Book de≈øired all his Chri≈øtan Brethren in the Deciding of this Que≈øtion to take the Word of God into their Hands, and with the Noble Bereans to ≈øit downe and examine, what≈øoever ≈øhall be ≈øaid on either ≈øide according to the Scriptures: I willingly make the ≈øame reque≈øt, as mo≈øt de≈øirous, that this ≈øhort An≈øwere may abide the like triall, and be weighed in the other ballance of the Sanctuary again≈øt the Doctors Booke.

Now that all things may be handled in good order, and in a
Methodicall way, the Doctor hath reduced the whole di≈øputation concerning this fir≈øt Que≈øtion into four Propo≈øitions, page. 11.
The fir≈øt, that there were many Congregations and ≈øeverall a≈ø≈øemblies of Beleevers in the church of Ieru≈øalem, in the which they enjoyed all acts of Wor≈øhip, and all the Ordinances among≈øt them≈øelves, and did partake of all acts of Church-fellow≈øhip, e≈øpecially of preaching, and in the Admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, and prayer, and that before the Per≈øecution we reade of, Act. 8.2.
The ≈øecond, That all the≈øe congregations, and ≈øeverall a≈ø≈øemblies made but one church.
The third, That the Apo≈øtles and Elders governed, ordered, and ruled this church joyntly, and by a Common-councell, and Preb≈øytery.
The fourth, that this church of Ieru≈øalem, and the government of the ≈øame is to be a patterne for all ≈øeverall congregations and a≈ø≈øemblies in any City or Vicinity to unite into one Church, and for the Officers of tho≈øe congregations to governe that Church joyntly in a Colledge or Pre≈øbyterie. The≈øe are his four Propo≈øitions.

But before hee comes to the proof of the≈øe particulars hee ≈øaith it will not bee ami≈ø≈øe in generall to take notice, That all the Churches we read of in the New Te≈øtament, were Ari≈øtocratically and Pre≈øtbyterially governed, and were all Dependent upon their ≈øeverall Presbyters, and produceth divers places of Scripture to prove the ≈øame, and two ≈øheets are ≈øpent wholly in proving thereof from the 12. page to the 29. All which (≈øhould it bee granted) only proves. Fir≈øt, That in every City or Church there was a Presbiterie, Acts. 14.23.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , cumque per ≈øuffragia ≈øtatui≈ø≈øent illis per ≈øingulas Eccle≈øias ≈øeniores, that is, When they had ordained them Elders in every Church by the Suffrage or ≈øtretching forth of Hands, al≈øo Titus 1.5.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , & con≈øtituas oppidatim ≈øeniores, that is, And thou maye≈øt Ordaine Elders towne by towne, or city by city, or village by village.

Secondly, that as there were Apo≈øtles and Elders in the Church of Jeru≈øalem, Act. 15.2,4. So there were Elders in the Church of Ephe≈øus, Act. 20.17,28. And in the Church of Corinth, and in the Church of Galatia, and in Philippie, &c.

Thirdly, that the≈øe ≈øeverall Churches were Dependent upon
their ≈øeverall Presbyters, and were to obey them who had the rule over them, Heb. 13.7,17,24. Or who were their Guides,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Obedite ducibus ve≈øtris, that is Obey your Guides.

Fourthly, that this Presbyterian-Church-Government, God hath hath appointed as his Ordinance, to be continued to the end of the world, the which who≈øoever re≈øi≈øteth, re≈øi≈øteth the Ordinance of God, but it doth not prove, That this Presbyterian-Church-Government is Dependent upon a ≈øupreame Judicature of a Common-coun≈øell of Presbyters, or that they mu≈øt ≈øubmit, and ≈øubject them them≈øelves and their churches unto the Decrees, Sentences, Con≈øtitutions, and Commandements, of a Common-councell, colledge, and court of cla≈ø≈øicall, or Synodall Presbyters, which the Doctor ≈øhould have proved, for ≈øuch a Presbyterian-Government he intends, as may appeare by the Doctors owne words, pag. 17.18. As for the Pre≈øbyterian Government (in the ≈øence that I under≈øtand it) there is nothing more cleare to me in all the Scripture: Yea the very word and name of Pre≈øbytery ≈øignifieth, a Magi≈øtracy, or Ari≈øtocracy, or Signory, or court. And as the word is taken in the civill Polity and Government, ≈øo in the Eccle≈øia≈øticall, by a Pre≈øbytery wee under≈øtand (≈øaith the Doctor) page 18. A Religious, Grave, Sollid, Learned, and Wi≈øe Councell of Divines, Mini≈øters, &c. Without who≈øe joynt and mutuall accord, or agreement and common-con≈øent nothing ought to be done or tran≈øacted of publicke concernment. And to make this good, to wit, That the Presbyters of particular congregations or a≈ø≈øemblies of Beleevers, and their Churches ought to be ≈øubject to a Common-councell or Court of Presbyters. The Doctor urgeth that Scripture, the third Epi≈øtle of John, the 9.10,11. ver≈øes, as an invincible Argument.

You ≈øhall finde it thus expounded by the Doctor pag. 15. 'And therefore when Diotrephes a≈ø≈øumed to him≈øelf, and his particular congregation a power and authority to rule according to his will and plea≈øure, without the con≈øent of the Presbyterie, and oppo≈øed Iohn the Presbyter, He ≈øharply reproves his proceedings, and ≈øignifies to the Church; That when he came he would remember
his words, and teach him how to prate again≈øt the Presbytery with malicious words; Which is an evill thing in him ≈øaith St. Iohn. It was evill in him to a≈ø≈øume unto him≈øelf, and his particular congregation, that power that belonged unto the colledge or councell of Presbyters, and was to be moderated and exerci≈øed onely by the conjoynt, and common-con≈øent of the Presbytery. For God hath appointed, that the Church ≈øhould be governed by a Presbytery; and Diotrephes would have his congregation Independent, and have an ab≈øolute jurisdiction within it ≈øelf, which ≈øaith St. Iohn is an evill thing.

Now let the Reader judge, whether the Dr. be not much mi≈øtaken in his Commentary-expo≈øition and application of this place of Scripture. And let me give you to under≈øtand, that St. Iohn ≈øaith ver≈øe 9. I wrote unto the Church. Or as Beza upon that ver≈øe,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Scrip≈øi nonnihil Eccle≈øiae, that is, I have written ≈øomething to the Church. But ≈øeeing no mention is made of any perticular Congregation, how can the Dr. ≈øo confidently affirm that it was his particular Congregation? Now the Reader may ≈øee plainly, That the Dr. can expound tho≈øe Brethren and their Elders or Presbyters, which the Scripture calles a Church, to be a particular Congregation. And what it was which St. Iohn had written to the Church is not in this Epi≈øtle, nor any other Scripture, declared, except it was, to receive tho≈øe Brethren, which he ≈øaith ver≈øe 8. ought to be received, and ver≈øe 10. whom Diotrephes would not receive, how then doth the Doctor ≈øay? That Diotrephes a≈ø≈øumed that power to him≈øelf, which belonged unto the Colledge and councell of Presbyters; without who≈øe joynt and mutuall agreement, and common-con≈øent nothing ought to be done or tran≈øacted of publike concernment. Is the receiving of Brethren, or ca≈øting out of Brethren a power which belongs to a Colledge of Presbyters, and neither the one nor the other may be tran≈øacted by the Elders and Brethren of a particular congregation, unle≈ø≈øe the court or common-councell of Presbyters conjoyntly con≈øent unto it? Let it be al≈øo con≈øidered, That Diotrephes oppo≈øed the Brethren and forbade them, that would have received tho≈øe, who St. Iohn ≈øaith ver≈øe 8. we ought to receive, yea and ca≈øt them ought, ver≈ø. 10.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
& volentes (admittere) prohibet
& de Eccle≈øia dejicit. That is, and forbiddeth them, that would (or are willing to admit them) and ca≈øteth them out of the church, to wit, excommunicates them. Doth it hereby appear that Diotrephes would have his congregation Independent? and have an ab≈øolute jurisdiction within it ≈øelf. No, but Diotrephes would Lord it over the church, and have the pre-eminence above his brethren, whether fellow Elders or fellow Saints, ver≈øe
‚Ä¢ .
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , ≈øed amans primatum gerere in eos Diorephes, that is, But Diotrephes loving the primacie among≈øt them. He would be the Primate and Metropolitan of the church, and have the Pre-eminence of all the Presbyters in it, and Brethren of it. The Doctor could have urged this Scripture again≈øt the domineering Prelates, and why ≈øhould he marvail, that his Brethren ≈øhould now urge it again≈øt the court of Presbyters. It is confe≈ø≈øed Diotrephes did that which was evill in u≈øurping Authority over the church, and tho≈øe Brethren, whom he ca≈øt out of the church; But that he was the fir≈øt that oppo≈øed the Presbyterian Government, or that he did affront a Court and common-councell of Presbyters, is more then I know, or the Doctor can prove. For had Diotrephes done ≈øo, why was he not convented before them, ≈øurely the Apo≈øtle and Elder St. Iohn would rather have written to the colledge of Presbyters (if there were any ≈øuch) then to the Church, or in writing to the Church, would rather have ≈øent him a ≈øummons to appear at ≈øome con≈øi≈øtorie before the Court and common-councell of Presbyters, then to warne them to take heed of his evill, that they did not follow it: And doubtle≈ø≈øe St. Iohn would have written thus, Diotrephes loves to be a Primate among you, wherefore when the Presbyterie that is to ≈øay, the Magi≈øtracy or Signory of grave, ≈øolid, learned, religious, and wi≈øe Divines and Mini≈øters come to keep order, and met together in a Court and common-councell, I will remember his deeds, and inform, or complain to the Court and common-councell of Presbyters, that he prates again≈øt us (the Presbyters) with malicious words. But the Apo≈øtle St. Iohn (did not know any Court or common-councell of Presbyters, neither Cla≈ø≈øicall, nor Synod call, to appeal unto) [Nor can the Doctor make good tho≈øe Appeales he mentioneth pag. 10. to be according to the Scripture of Truth, to wit;
That every particular man, as well as any A≈ø≈øembly or Congregation, may have their appeal to the Presbyterie of their Precinct, hundred, or devi≈øion under who≈øe jurisdictions they were; And if they finde them≈øelves wronged there, then they have appeales to ≈øome other higher Presbytery or Councell of Divines for relief and ju≈øtice. I onely ask the Doctor how he can prove the≈øe appeales by Scripture; and if he could, whether that higher Presbytery or Councell of Divines, (e≈øpecially if they may ≈øay the Holy Gho≈øt and we) be not as Independent as the≈øe Brethren and their Churches, again≈øt whom the Doctor hath written: And if ≈øo, then ≈øuch a high Presbytery or Councell of Divines, is not Gods Ordintnce, by the Doctors own confe≈ø≈øion and Affirmation.] Therefore the Apo≈øtle writes to the Church or perticular Congregation whereof Diotrephes was a Member and an Elder, whom he knew had power to judge him, as well as the Church or perticular Congregation of Corinth had power to judge them that were Members therein. 1 Cor. 5.12.13. And therefore might as warrantably admoni≈øh Diotrephes, as the Church of Colo≈ø≈øe might Arckippus: Colo≈ø≈ø. 4.17. 'And if nothing of publike concernment ought to bee done or tran≈øacted without the joynt and mutuall accord or agreement, and common con≈øent of the Presbytery; Iohn the Presbyter would not have tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed ≈øo farre, as to take upon him≈øelf this Authority over Diotrephes to tell the Church of his faults, and to ≈øay he would remember him and ≈øharply reprove him, and teach him to prate again≈øt the Presbyterie with malicious words, which belonged to the Court and Common Councell of Presbyters: But I ≈øhall have a ju≈øt occa≈øion to ≈øay more touching this matter in the an≈øwer unto the third Que≈øtion, and therefore pa≈øsing by the objection with its an≈øwer mentioned page 19. to the 29. unto its due place. I ≈øhall de≈øire ≈øeriou≈øly to con≈øider the Doctors proof of his fir≈øt propo≈øition, which he laboureth fir≈øt by producing ≈øuch Scriptures, as he conceiveth make for the manife≈øtation of the Truth, and from thence frames and formeth his Arguments. 'His Scriptures are the≈øe, viz. Matth. 3. ver≈ø. 1.2.5.6. Mark. 6.20.21. Matth. 14.5. and Luk. 20.4.6. And divers other Scriptures, which you have at large ≈øet down in the Doctors Book with his Arguments framed from thence, pag. 29. to 82. where this fir≈øt propo≈øition endeth. The ≈øumme of all which, I ≈øhall give the Reader to under≈øtand as briefly as I can, to wit; 'Where there was an infinite
multitude of Beleevers, or a very City of Beleevers, ≈øo that they kept a tyrannicall King in awe, and all the Magi≈øtrates and Elders in who≈øe hands was all the power and Authority, even a world of Beleevers, with many Rulers and men of great place and and Office, with ≈øuch an increa≈øe of multitudes of Beleevers, 8000 new Converts be≈øides women and children, yea many 10000, of Beleevers, and where there were almo≈øt an hundred Preachers and Mini≈øters, be≈øides the 12. Apo≈øtles, and all the≈øe continually taken up in Prayer and Preaching, There mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie be many Congregations and A≈ø≈øemblies. But in the Church of Jeru≈øalem there was an infinite multitude of Beleevers, and a very City of Beleevers (which kept Herod him≈øelf, the tyrant in awe, and all the Magi≈øtrates and Elders) even a world of Beleevers, with many Rulers and men of great place and Office, with an increa≈øe of multitudes of Beleevers, and 8000. new Converts be≈øides women and children, yea and many 10000. after all the per≈øecutions, and almo≈øt an hundred Preachers and Mini≈øters be≈øides the 12 Apo≈øtles, and all the≈øe were continually taken up in Prayer and Preaching; Ergo, they mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øitie be di≈øpier≈øed into many Congregations and ≈øeverall A≈ø≈øemblies. I do deny the Minor propo≈øition of this Argument. Neither hath the Doctor proved, That there was an infinite number of Beleevers, nor a very City of Beleevers in the Church of Jeru≈øalem. The Scriptures quoted by the Doctor ≈øpeakes no ≈øuch thing; tho≈øe places in Matthew, Mark and Luke, tell us of very many who were baptized by Iohn, and by Chri≈øts Di≈øciples, but do not declare how many of the≈øe baptized per≈øons were of the Church in Jeru≈øalem; and the Scripture witne≈ø≈øeth Acts 9.31. that there were Churches throughout all Judaea, as well as in Jeru≈øalem, and for ought I know, or the Doctor either, many of tho≈øe baptized per≈øons might be in the≈øe Churches, yea the mo≈øt of them, and but a few, it may be no more but tho≈øe 120. mentioned Acts 1.13,14,15. To whom were added about 3000. ≈øouls, who continued in the Apo≈øtles Doctrine, and fellow≈øhip, and in breaking of bread and in prayers. Acts 2.41.42.44.46. And as for the world of Beleevers mentioned in another argument drawn from Joh. 12.19. behold the world is gone after him.Pag. 37 and 40. That Scripture doth not ≈øay they beleeved in him, much le≈ø≈øe that there was a world of Beleevers in the Church in Ieru≈øalem. Neither is there mention in any Scripture quoted by the Doctor of
8000. new Converts be≈øides women and children. Neither doth that Scripture produced Acts 4.4 prove any ≈øuch thing: For the Reader may con≈øider that the number of them there mentioned are but 5000. And albeit the Doctor make them up 8000. by ≈øaying tho≈øe 5000. men were added to the Church, and joyned to the formers Beleevers pag. 57. Yet there is a twofold mi≈øtake in the Doctors Addition, to wit; Fir≈øt, that ≈øome of the 3000. (may be) were women, and how then can the Doctor ≈øay, there were 8000. new converts be≈øides women. Secondly, the≈øe 5000. are onely called men and not converts, not beleevers. For howbeit many of them hearing the Word beleeved, yet it is not ≈øaid the 5000. men beleeved: And the truth is the Text well con≈øidered only holds forth, that, the number of men was made up five thou≈øand.
